history.content:
UPE has a book of samples from their students who have successfully secured great offers: https://upe.cs.berkeley.edu/#main-wrapper

This is also a really valuable resource: https://career.berkeley.edu/Guide/Guide

children.subject: Where can I find the resumes on the UPE page?

history.content:
UPE offers resume critique and other professional development resources such as Mock Techincal Interviews. Once the year starts, the signups will be available for interviews and office hours for resume critique. In the meantime, feel free to email <profdev@upe.berkeley.edu> and we do our best to give your feedback during the summer. Closer to the start of the year, we also hope to release more resources to help students with their professional development on our website. 
As a clarification, we do not have a public resume book at the moment, but are happy to give personalized feedback. 

-----------------------------------------------
If you put your email here, I can send you my resume as a latex file so you can edit it and put your own info in. I've heard good feedback about it and have gotten it critiqued several times by professionals.

UPE offers resume critique and other professional development resources such as Mock Techincal Interviews. Once the year starts, the signups will be available for interviews and office hours for resume critique. In the meantime, feel free to email <profdev@upe.berkeley.edu> and we do our best to give your feedback during the summer. Closer to the start of the year, we also hope to release more resources to help students with their professional development on our website. 

As a clarification, we do not have a public resume book at the moment, but are happy to give personalized feedback.

UPE offers resume critique and other professional development resources such as Mock Techincal Interviews. Once the year starts, the signups will be available for interviews and office hours for resume critique. In the meantime, feel free to email <profdev@upe.berkeley.edu> and we do our best to give your feedback during the summer. Closer to the start of the year, we also hope to release more resources to help students with their professional development on our website. 

As a clarification, we do not have a public resume book at the moment, but are happy to give personalized feedback.

children.subject: I would recommend Latex-ing it, following Deedy Das template. It is accessible in Overleaf. Emphasize previous relevant work experience and projects. In my opinion those are the two most important things by far. Tailor your resume for each place you are applying and try to avoid having irrelevant stuff as much as you can (if you still do not have enough relevant work experience or projects it is fine for now, but actively work to get rid off resume fillers). Personal projects or projects your worked for in industry are definitely more desirable than class projects, but if you do not have enough of them, feel free to put some of the most challenging ones that you've done in your classes and that you feel comfortable explaining if you were to be asked. Overall try to make sure that no two things in your resume highlight the same skills

Latex definitely has a lot of good templates! I personally used this one, and modified it to look how I wanted it to look.

Highlight work experience; the education section should just list your relevant schools (Berkeley) plus your major and GPA, and it can help to have a separate section for relevant coursework (esp for courses that relate directly to the job you're applying for). 

If you do have a lot of work experience, I've also been told by recruiters that it's nice to include an extracurriculars section if you're particularly passionate about something not directly relating to your major. Shows that you're a well-rounded person and demonstrates traits like dedication :D

If OP wants to see a filled out example, feel free to reply to this and I can DM you mine or something.

Oh also, class projects are totally fine to include. I included gitlet and Database from 61B because I thought they were super worthwhile, and they're built from scratch so you did truly code it yourself.

Some suggestions I have based on the follow up: 

class projects are alright if you don’t have other stuff, but be sure to be unique. If everyone else has the same class project, recruiters won’t give it much weight but class projects that are unique might be better. In general, I recommend staying away from class projects, but you can certainly use them if they show something unique about you. 

For GPA being optional, I know most people/companies don’t put too much weight on it as long as your projects or work experience is good, and I think it’s mixed when it comes to whether you should or shouldn’t. Recruiters/engineers I have spoken to have said you should have it, since if it is decent, they won’t pay much attention to it. If you don’t have it, they can assume the worst GPA. I would suggest you have it, even if it isn’t a super spectacular GPA.
In your opinion, is it better to list a small personal project (such as a web app that uses an API) or a larger class project (such as the bigger 61B projects)?

I think it will be dependent on what type of job you are looking for and what you have included in your resume. For example, if you have nothing in your resume that showcases your ability to do something in webdev, you probably want to make something that uses react, css, html or something similar. Same would apply to any other situation.

If you are interested in Software engineering I feel that your priority should be focused along the idea of putting projects that highlight your ability to design systems (apps, 61b and 162 kind of projects, games, etc might be your best bet). If you are into ML, you might want to include projects about signal/image processing and analysis, text analysis, etc.

I would list at least 2 projects in the domain I am working on and 1 other project in something else
yea, I normally cater my resume to the company/ job to which I am applying. Thanks for the response :)

I'd say projects are the MOST important for CS students. My resume has education on the top (small section with school, relevant classes, and GPA(optional) )

Then 80% of the resumes split in half into projects and work experience

Also tailor your resume to each job/field. I keep a different document with a list of my experiences with a description of each, and copy and paste from that for each job's resume. For just CS though, def put down things like internships and research, and only add other non-tech jobs if u have space, if at all.

Projects are SUPER important and treat that section just like the work experience one. Each side/class project is a job, and describe what you did for it as such. 

Links are good too (for github, linkedIn, projects), but make sure to put them on a tinyurl so it's easy to access 

good luck!!

history.content:
If possible, would anyone mind posting a version that has worked for them in the past. Looking for Berkeley student specific resumes so I know what are good things to put under education!

Thanks!
